text:
Back prices because they're generally more reliable and consistent than lay prices. However, unlike your screenshot they won't add up to 100%.

Moreover, low-priced odds can be shown to be closer to true than long-priced ones, so the adjustment needed to isn't linear.

The Shin approach is a well-proven, non-linear approach to making these adjustments. There's a <https://github.com/mberk/shin|package> to make this easy.

What you have in your screenshot looks a like an implementation of the Harville method for deriving probabilities of placing from the win equivalents.

This comes from an old paper published by a chap called (unsurprisingly) Harville. It's a purely mathematical approach and has been shown to be flawed in real-life.

attachments.text: Python implementation of Shin's method for calculating implied probabilities from bookmaker odds
attachments.title: mberk/shin

text: <@U9JHLMZB4> when you say that "low-priced odds can be shown to be closer to true than long-priced ones", does this hold for Betfair Exchange? I read a paper that shows this is true for bookmakers, but in an Exchange there is no incentive in lowering the long-priced odds.

elements.text: when you say that "low-priced odds can be shown to be closer to true than long-priced ones", does this hold for Betfair Exchange? I read a paper that shows this is true for bookmakers, but in an Exchange there is no incentive in lowering the long-priced odds.

text:
<@U0155J92A7Q> longshot-favourite bias isn't just about bookie behaviour, it's also about bettors willingness to accept a lower price if the price is big enough, or more cynically punters inability to accurately evaluate true value when the potential winnings are big.

This applies also to the Betfair Exchange and the smaller spreads (in % terms) between back and lay at the low end of the market tend to support this.

text: <@U03TJKFLE8K> Simple example. Jockey is riding a horse with a reasonable chance of winning, and is instructed by the trainer that if it looks like it's got a shot, go for it, otherwise hold back (so that it doesn't pick up too much weight when handicapped for the next race). In this case the win odds may be fair, but a purely mathematical derivation of the place odds would overstate them.

text: Bit of a noob question, but what's the recommended beginner friendly way to manage/automate python venv's on a Linux production machine? To be more specific, I've only used venv's created by Pycharm on my development machine but now I'm getting to a point where I have old bots chugging away in production but need to run others with newer libraries . Venv is the obvious way to achieve this without fucking up the older ones running on the main system, but I'm wondering how best to automate venv installation and setup for spinning up new bot instances on a single machine?

elements.text: Bit of a noob question, but what's the recommended beginner friendly way to manage/automate python venv's on a Linux production machine? To be more specific, I've only used venv's created by Pycharm on my development machine but now I'm getting to a point where I have old bots chugging away in production but need to run others with newer libraries . Venv is the obvious way to achieve this without fucking up the older ones running on the main system, but I'm wondering how best to automate venv installation and setup for spinning up new bot instances on a single machine?

text: I got in a right muddle with PyCharm switching back from 3.10 to 3.9 because it broke something. You'd have to create a new project as I understand it for you new bots and set the environment for that new project. Think found my answers at <https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm/configuring-python-interpreter.html#modify_interpreter>

attachments.fallback: PyCharm Help: Configure a Python interpreter | PyCharm
attachments.title: Configure a Python interpreter | PyCharm

text: I use virtualenv in production, along with tmux. It's a pretty straightforward way of creating independent python environments.

elements.text: I use virtualenv in production, along with tmux. It's a pretty straightforward way of creating independent python environments.

text:
<@U02RN7YDRQ9> I'm fine with Pycharm on my development machine. My production stuff is on a headless Linux VPS. :+1: 
<@URMM9463X> I'm thinking more along the lines of automating the setup & launch via a script. It seems like a common workflow for which management tools would already exist but Google has muddied the waters and/or I'm not using the correct terminology. My basic manual workflow would be something like:
1. login to remote server via SSH
2. create venv
3. activate venv & install libraries (Flumine, etc)
4. git clone strategy code
5. launch python strategy
6. logout of SSH

text:
I'd suggest <https://pipenv.pypa.io/en/latest/|Pipenv> for managing the spec for a virtualenv, it can create (by default IIR) a virtualenv under `.venv` (you don't want to commit that), and uses a `Pipfile` and `Pipfile.lock` to manage what goes into the venvs it manages.

The useful thing is that you specify the package constraints in your `Pipfile` (e.g. `pandas ~= 1.1.0`),  then you can tell it to update the lockfile with the latest versions that satisfy the constraints, and you can sync your environments using `pipenv` - perfect for developing services with virtualenvs.

text: <@U01C12ZEADQ> I assume from the phrasing of your question that you've seen the <https://www.sciencepublishinggroup.com/journal/paperinfo?journalid=155&doi=10.11648/j.ajss.20170506.12|Clarke et al> paper promotes the use of the power method but you're looking for more practical evidence?

attachments.fallback: Adjusting Bookmaker’s Odds to Allow for Overround :: Science Publishing Group
attachments.text: Several methods have been proposed to adjust bookmakers’ implied probabilities, including an additive model, a normalization model, and an iterative method proposed by Shin. These approaches have one or more defects: the additive model can give negative adjusted probabilities, normalization does not account for favorite long-shot bias, and both the normalization and Shin approaches can produce bookmaker probabilities greater than 1 when applied in reverse. Moreover, it is shown that the Shin and additive methods are equivalent for races with two competitors. Vovk and Zhadanov (2009) and Clarke (2016) suggested a power method, where the implied probabilities are raised to a fixed power, which never produces bookmaker or fair probabilities outside the 0-1 range and allows for the favorite long-shot bias. This paper describes and applies the methods to three large bookmaker datasets, each in a different sport, and shows that the power method universally outperforms the multiplicative method and outperforms or is comparable to the Shin method.
attachments.title: Adjusting Bookmaker’s Odds to Allow for Overround :: Science Publishing Group

elements.text: I assume from the phrasing of your question that you've seen the
Clarke et al
paper promotes the use of the power method but you're looking for more practical evidence?
